bioghist.p: David Earl Mattern was a professor of Music Education in the School of Music at the University of Michigan from 1929 to his death in 1959. His career spanned forty years, with activities ranging from playing first violin for the Rochester Philharmonic Orchestra to conducting the University of Michigan's "Under and Over Sixty Club."

Born in 1890, Mattern was a 1906 graduate of Newton High School in Newton, Iowa. The proof from his 1957 entry in Who's Who in America provides a detailed outline of his education and stages of his career. Mattern married Viola Smith on April 21, 1924, and Shirley Mattern (later Mrs. Haldon Smith) was born to them in 1925.

Early in his career, Mattern taught summer session instruction of violin classes at Cornell, the Eastman School of Music, and Ithaca College. In 1926, he moved to Grand Rapids, Michigan, to become the supervisor of music for the public schools. During his three years in Grand Rapids, he also conducted the Schubert Club, a large male chorus.

In 1929, Mattern was offered a position at the University of Michigan in the area of music education. From 1929 to 1931, he conducted the University Symphony Orchestra, and from 1931 to 1947, he was the director of the Men's Glee Club. Mattern was also involved as the director of music for the University School in the School of Education beginning in 1931.

Mattern's interest in music education reached beyond a person's formal school years, leading him to take on a position as director of the Detroit Extension Orchestra. This program, administered by the University's Extension Service, allowed adult residents of the southeast corner of the state to gather and participate in high quality amateur performances. The orchestra's repertoire included the masters and the classics.

Mattern was associated professionally with the: [Michigan] State Committee on Creative Arts, Michigan String Quartet Festivals, Music Teachers' National Association, Music Educator's National Conference, [Michigan] State Advisory Council on Music Education, and the Michigan School Band and Orchestra Association.

scopecontent.p: The David Earl Mattern Papers document Mattern's education and career from 1905 to his death in 1959. The collection is organized in four series: Biographical and Personal Materials, Education, Professional Career, and Photographs. Topics covered extensively in this collection include the University of Michigan Men's Glee Club, the Extension Orchestra, and Mattern's activities during the university's Summer Session.

scopecontent.p: The Biographical and Personal Materials series contains several biographical articles. Also included are other personal papers relating to the purchase of a lot, and the settling of his estate after his death. In 1972, Merle Hanson, a doctoral candidate in the School of Music, requested Viola Mattern's and Shirley Smith's permission to base his dissertation on Professor Mattern's career, and his proposal is included here.
Education consists of grade cards from Mattern's late high school years, some class notes from Cornell, and his summer session degree in music for public schools.

The Professional Career series begins with papers about Mattern's early work in Pennsylvania, teaching and playing professionally, and his work in the mid 1920s in Kalamazoo and Grand Rapids. These are followed by copies of Mattern's numerous publications, speeches and lectures. Mattern was very active in the University of Michigan Symphony Orchestra in the 1930s, and the Michigan School Band and Orchestra Association throughout his time at the University.

Within this series are six folders relating to Mattern's work with the U of M Men's Glee Club, which he conducted from 1931 to 1947. Included are programs, clippings and business materials, also two folders of letters from men of the Glee Club serving in the armed forced during World War II.

Mattern's involvement in the University Extension Orchestra is also documented in the Professional Career series. Beside the programs, business correspondence and clippings, there is a folder of letters from the participants in the orchestra, many of which are not dated. The Summer Sessions files relates to arrangements for summer instructors for music education classes at the University of Michigan. These have been arranged chronologically.
